column2: We walked on until we reached that part of the Canongate street in which she lodged.
column3: We walked on until we reached that part of the Canongate street in which she lodged.

column2: We stopped at the door.
column3: We stopped at the door.

column2: CHAPTER XI.
column3: CHAPTER eleven.

column2: THE LETTER OF INTRODUCTION.
column3: THE LETTER OF INTRODUCTION.

column2: I LOOKED at the house.
column3: I LOOKED at the house.

column2: It was an inn, of no great size, but of respectable appearance.
column3: It was an inn, of no great size, but of respectable appearance.

column2: If I was to be of any use to her that night, the time had come to speak of other subjects than the subject of dreams.
column3: If I was to be of any use to her that night, the time had come to speak of other subjects than the subject of dreams.

column2: After all that you have told me, I said, "I will not ask you to admit me any further into your confidence until we meet again.
column3: After all that you have told me, I said, "I will not ask you to admit me any further into your confidence until we meet again.

column2: Only let me hear how I can relieve your most pressing anxieties.
column3: Only let me hear how I can relieve your most pressing anxieties.

column2: What are your plans?
column3: What are your plans?

column2: Can I do anything to help them before you go to rest to-night?"
column3: Can I do anything to help them before you go to rest to night?"

column2: She thanked me warmly, and hesitated, looking up the street and down the street in evident embarrassment what to say next.
column3: She thanked me warmly, and hesitated, looking up the street and down the street in evident embarrassment what to say next.

column2: Do you propose staying in Edinburgh? I asked.
column3: Do you propose staying in Edinburgh? I asked.

column2: Oh no! I don't wish to remain in Scotland.	Oh no! I don't wish to remain in Scotland.
column3: true

column2: I want to go much further away.
column3: I want to go much further away.

column2: I think I should do better in London; at some respectable milliner's, if I could be properly recommended.
column3: I think I should do better in London; at some respectable milliner's, if I could be properly recommended.

column2: I am quick at my needle, and I understand cutting out.
column3: I am quick at my needle, and I understand cutting out.

column2: Or I could keep accounts, if--if anybody would trust me."
column3: Or I could keep accounts, if-if anybody would trust me."

column2: She stopped, and looked at me doubtingly, as if she felt far from sure, poor soul, of winning my confidence to begin with.
column3: She stopped, and looked at me doubtingly, as if she felt far from sure, poor soul, of winning my confidence to begin with.

column2: I acted on that hint, with the headlong impetuosity of a man who was in love.
column3: I acted on that hint, with the headlong impetuosity of a man who was in love.

column2: I can give you exactly the recommendation you want, I said, "whenever you like.
column3: I can give you exactly the recommendation you want, I said, "whenever you like.

column2: Now, if you would prefer it."
column3: Now, if you would prefer it."

column2: Her charming features brightened with pleasure.
column3: Her charming features brightened with pleasure.

column2: Oh, you are indeed a friend to me! she said, impulsively.
column3: Oh, you are indeed a friend to me! she said, impulsively.

column2: Her face clouded again--she saw my proposal in a new light.
column3: Her face clouded again-she saw my proposal in a new light.

column2: Have I any right, she asked, sadly, "to accept what you offer me?"
column3: Have I any right, she asked, sadly, "to accept what you offer me?"

column2: Let me give you the letter, I answered, "and you can decide for yourself whether you will use it or not."
column3: Let me give you the letter, I answered, "and you can decide for yourself whether you will use it or not."

column2: I put her arm again in mine, and entered the inn.
column3: I put her arm again in mine, and entered the inn.

column2: She shrunk back in alarm.
column3: She shrunk back in alarm.

column2: What would the landlady think if she saw her lodger enter the house at night in company with a stranger, and that stranger a gentleman?
column3: What would the landlady think if she saw her lodger enter the house at night in company with a stranger, and that stranger a gentleman?

column2: The landlady appeared as she made the objection. Reckless what I said or what I did, I introduced myself as her relative, and asked to be shown into a quiet room in which I could write a letter. After one sharp glance at me, the landlady appeared to be satisfied that she was dealing with a gentleman.
column3: The landlady appeared as she made the objection. Reckless what I said or what I did, I introduced myself as her relative, and asked to be shown into a quiet room in which I could write a letter. After one sharp glance at me, the landlady appeared to be satisfied that she was dealing with a gentleman.

column2: She led the way into a sort of parlor behind the "bar," placed writing materials on the table, looked at my companion as only one woman can look at another under certain circumstances, and left us by ourselves.
column3: She led the way into a sort of parlor behind the "bar," placed writing materials on the table, looked at my companion as only one woman can look at another under certain circumstances, and left us by ourselves.

column2: It was the first time I had ever been in a room with her alone. The embarrassing sense of her position had heightened her color and brightened her eyes.
column3: It was the first time I had ever been in a room with her alone. The embarrassing sense of her position had heightened her color and brightened her eyes.

column2: She stood, leaning one hand on the table, confused and irresolute, her firm and supple figure falling into an attitude of unsought grace which it was literally a luxury to look at.
column3: She stood, leaning one hand on the table, confused and irresolute, her firm and supple figure falling into an attitude of unsought grace which it was literally a luxury to look at.

column2: I said nothing; my eyes confessed my admiration; the writing materials lay untouched before me on the table.
column3: I said nothing; my eyes confessed my admiration; the writing materials lay untouched before me on the table.

column2: How long the silence might have lasted I cannot say.
column3: How long the silence might have lasted I cannot say.

column2: She abruptly broke it.
column3: She abruptly broke it.

column2: Her instinct warned her that silence might have its dangers, in our position.
column3: Her instinct warned her that silence might have its dangers, in our position.

column2: She turned to me with an effort; she said, uneasily, "I don't think you ought to write your letter to-night, sir."
column3: She turned to me with an effort; she said, uneasily, "I don't think you ought to write your letter to night, sir."

column2: Why not?
column3: Why not?

column2: You know nothing of me.	You know nothing of me.
column3: true

column2: Surely you ought not to recommend a person who is a stranger to you?
column3: Surely you ought not to recommend a person who is a stranger to you?

column2: And I am worse than a stranger.
column3: And I am worse than a stranger.

column2: I am a miserable wretch who has tried to commit a great sin--I have tried to destroy myself.
column3: I am a miserable wretch who has tried to commit a great sin-I have tried to destroy myself.

column2: Perhaps the misery I was in might be some excuse for me, if you knew it.
column3: Perhaps the misery I was in might be some excuse for me, if you knew it.

column2: You ought to know it.
column3: You ought to know it.

column2: But it's so late to-night, and I am so sadly tired--and there are some things, sir, which it is not easy for a woman to speak of in the presence of a man."
column3: But it's so late to night, and I am so sadly tired-and there are some things, sir, which it is not easy for a woman to speak of in the presence of a man."

column2: Her head sunk on her bosom; her delicate lips trembled a little; she said no more.
column3: Her head sunk on her bosom; her delicate lips trembled a little; she said no more.

column2: The way to reassure and console her lay plainly enough before me, if I chose to take it.
column3: The way to reassure and console her lay plainly enough before me, if I chose to take it.

column2: Without stopping to think, I took it.
column3: Without stopping to think, I took it.

column2: Reminding her that she had herself proposed writing to me when we met that evening, I suggested that she should wait to tell the sad story of her troubles until it was convenient to her to send me the narrative in the form of a letter.
column3: Reminding her that she had herself proposed writing to me when we met that evening, I suggested that she should wait to tell the sad story of her troubles until it was convenient to her to send me the narrative in the form of a letter.

column2: In the mean time, I added, "I have the most perfect confidence in you; and I beg as a favor that you will let me put it to the proof.
column3: In the mean time, I added, "I have the most perfect confidence in you; and I beg as a favor that you will let me put it to the proof.

column2: I can introduce you to a dressmaker in London who is at the head of a large establishment, and I will do it before I leave you to-night."
column3: I can introduce you to a dressmaker in London who is at the head of a large establishment, and I will do it before I leave you to night."

column2: I dipped my pen in the ink as I said the words.
column3: I dipped my pen in the ink as I said the words.

column2: Let me confess frankly the lengths to which my infatuation led me.
column3: Let me confess frankly the lengths to which my infatuation led me.

column2: The dressmaker to whom I had alluded had been my mother's maid in f ormer years, and had been established in business with money lent by my late step-father, Mr. Germaine.
column3: The dressmaker to whom I had alluded had been my mother's maid in f ormer years, and had been established in business with money lent by my late step father, mr Germaine.

column2: I used both their names without scruple; and I wrote my recommendation in terms which the best of living women and the ablest of existing dressmakers could never have hoped to merit.
column3: I used both their names without scruple; and I wrote my recommendation in terms which the best of living women and the ablest of existing dressmakers could never have hoped to merit.

column2: Will anybody find excuses for me?
column3: Will anybody find excuses for me?

column2: Those rare persons who have been in love, and who have not completely forgotten it yet, may perhaps find excuses for me.
column3: Those rare persons who have been in love, and who have not completely forgotten it yet, may perhaps find excuses for me.

column2: It matters little; I don't deserve them.
column3: It matters little; I don't deserve them.

column2: I handed her the open letter to read.
column3: I handed her the open letter to read.

column2: She blushed delightfully; she cast one tenderly grateful look at me, which I remembered but too well for many and many an after-day.
column3: She blushed delightfully; she cast one tenderly grateful look at me, which I remembered but too well for many and many an after day.

column2: The next moment, to my astonishment, this changeable creature changed again.
column3: The next moment, to my astonishment, this changeable creature changed again.

column2: Some forgotten consideration seemed to have occurred to her.
column3: Some forgotten consideration seemed to have occurred to her.

column2: She turned pale; the soft lines of pleasure in her face hardened, little by little; she regarded me with the saddest look of confusion and distress.
column3: She turned pale; the soft lines of pleasure in her face hardened, little by little; she regarded me with the saddest look of confusion and distress.

column2: Putting the letter down before me on the table, she said, timidly:
column3: Putting the letter down before me on the table, she said, timidly:

column2: Would you mind adding a postscript, sir?
column3: Would you mind adding a postscript, sir?

column2: I suppressed all appearance of surprise as well as I could, and took up the pen again.
column3: I suppressed all appearance of surprise as well as I could, and took up the pen again.

column2: Would you please say, she went on, "that I am only to be taken on trial, at first?
column3: Would you please say, she went on, "that I am only to be taken on trial, at first?

column2: I am not to be engaged for more"--her voice sunk lower and lower, so that I could barely hear the next words--"for more than three months, certain."
column3: I am not to be engaged for more"--her voice sunk lower and lower, so that I could barely hear the next words-"for more than three months, certain."

column2: It was not in human nature--perhaps I ought to say it was not in the nature of a man who was in my situation--to refrain from showing some curiosity, on being asked to supplement a letter of recommendation by such a postscript as this.
column3: It was not in human nature-perhaps I ought to say it was not in the nature of a man who was in my situation-to refrain from showing some curiosity, on being asked to supplement a letter of recommendation by such a postscript as this.

column2: Have you some other employment in prospect? I asked.
column3: Have you some other employment in prospect? I asked.

column2: None, she answered, with her head down, and her eyes avoiding mine.
column3: None, she answered, with her head down, and her eyes avoiding mine.

column2: An unworthy doubt of her--the mean offspring of jealousy--found its way into my mind.
column3: An unworthy doubt of her-the mean offspring of jealousy-found its way into my mind.

column2: Have you some absent friend, I went on, "who is likely to prove a better friend than I am, if you only give him time?"
column3: Have you some absent friend, I went on, "who is likely to prove a better friend than I am, if you only give him time?"

column2: She lifted her noble head.
column3: She lifted her noble head.

column2: Her grand, guileless gray eyes rested on me with a look of patient reproach.
column3: Her grand, guileless gray eyes rested on me with a look of patient reproach.

column2: I have not got a friend in the world, she said.
column3: I have not got a friend in the world, she said.

column2: For God's sake, ask me no more questions to-night!
column3: For God's sake, ask me no more questions to night!

column2: I rose and gave her the letter once more--with the postscript added, in her own words.
column3: I rose and gave her the letter once more-with the postscript added, in her own words.

column2: We stood together by the table; we looked at each other in a momentary silence.
column3: We stood together by the table; we looked at each other in a momentary silence.

column2: How can I thank you? she murmured, softly.
column3: How can I thank you? she murmured, softly.

column2: Oh, sir, I will indeed be worthy of the confidence that you have shown in me! Her eyes moistened; her variable color came and went; her dress heaved softly over the lovely outline of her bosom.
column3: Oh, sir, I will indeed be worthy of the confidence that you have shown in me! Her eyes moistened; her variable color came and went; her dress heaved softly over the lovely outline of her bosom.

column2: I don't believe the man lives who could have resisted her at that moment.
column3: I don't believe the man lives who could have resisted her at that moment.

column2: I lost all power of restraint; I caught her in my arms; I whispered, "I love you!" I kissed her passionately.
column3: I lost all power of restraint; I caught her in my arms; I whispered, "I love you!" I kissed her passionately.

column2: For a moment she lay helpless and trembling on my breast; for a moment her fragrant lips softly returned the kiss.
column3: For a moment she lay helpless and trembling on my breast; for a moment her fragrant lips softly returned the kiss.

column2: In an instant more it was over.
column3: In an instant more it was over.

column2: She tore herself away with a shudder that shook her from head to foot, and threw the letter that I had given to her indignantly at my feet.
column3: She tore herself away with a shudder that shook her from head to foot, and threw the letter that I had given to her indignantly at my feet.

column2: How dare you take advantage of me!	How dare you take advantage of me!
column3: true

column2: How dare you touch me!" she said. "Take your letter back, sir; I refuse to receive it; I will never speak to you again.
column3: How dare you touch me!" she said. "Take your letter back, sir; I refuse to receive it; I will never speak to you again.

column2: You don't know what you have done.
column3: You don't know what you have done.

column2: You don't know how deeply you have wounded me.
column3: You don't know how deeply you have wounded me.

column2: Oh!" she cried, throwing herself in despair on a sofa that stood near her, "shall I ever recover my self-respect? shall I ever forgive myself for what I have done to-night?"
column3: Oh!" she cried, throwing herself in despair on a sofa that stood near her, "shall I ever recover my self respect? shall I ever forgive myself for what I have done to night?"

column2: I implored her pardon; I assured her of my repentance and regret in words which did really come from my heart.
column3: I implored her pardon; I assured her of my repentance and regret in words which did really come from my heart.

column2: The violence of her agitation more than distressed me--I was really alarmed by it.
column3: The violence of her agitation more than distressed me-I was really alarmed by it.

column2: She composed herself after a while.
column3: She composed herself after a while.

column2: She rose to her feet with modest dignity, and silently held out her hand in token that my repentance was accepted.
column3: She rose to her feet with modest dignity, and silently held out her hand in token that my repentance was accepted.

column2: You will give me time for atonement? I pleaded.
column3: You will give me time for atonement? I pleaded.

column2: You will not lose all confidence in me?	You will not lose all confidence in me?
column3: true

column2: Let me see you again, if it is only to show that I am not quite unworthy of your pardon--at your own time; in the presence of another person, if you like."
column3: Let me see you again, if it is only to show that I am not quite unworthy of your pardon-at your own time; in the presence of another person, if you like."

column2: I will write to you, she said.
column3: I will write to you, she said.

column2: To-morrow?
column3: To morrow?

column2: To-morrow.
column3: To morrow.

column2: I took up the letter of recommendation from the floor.
column3: I took up the letter of recommendation from the floor.

column2: Make your goodness to me complete, I said.
column3: Make your goodness to me complete, I said.

column2: Don't mortify me by refusing to take my letter.
column3: Don't mortify me by refusing to take my letter.

column2: I will take your letter, she answered, quietly.
column3: I will take your letter, she answered, quietly.

column2: Thank you for writing it.	Thank you for writing it.
column3: true

column2: Leave me now, please.
column3: Leave me now, please.

column2: Good-night."
column3: Good night."

column2: I left her, pale and sad, with my letter in her hand.
column3: I left her, pale and sad, with my letter in her hand.

column2: I left her, with my mind in a tumult of contending emotions, which gradually resolved themselves into two master-feelings as I walked on: Love, that adored her more fervently than ever; and Hope, that set the prospect before me of seeing her again on the next day.
column3: I left her, with my mind in a tumult of contending emotions, which gradually resolved themselves into two master feelings as I walked on: Love, that adored her more fervently than ever; and Hope, that set the prospect before me of seeing her again on the next day.
